This gender difference in attitudes towards divorce leads to an association between divorcees and women with criminal behavior, a belief that was common in Spain before and shortly after reforms to the social security system which aim to ensure economic viability of divorced women.

According to the 27% of men in my survey who believe that women with divorced status are more at-risk of committing crimes, those critical of norms concerning women and criminal behavior tend to believe that women commit more crimes, possibly because of a more pronounced sense of material insecurity.

The findings of my research also suggest that men’s hostility towards divorced women may be linked to gender role attitudes, including views about women and divorce, which were found to outweigh perceptions of economic deprivation. More educated and middle class men in the sample were found to hold hostile attitudinal beliefs towards women with divorced status, possibly because such men are more accustomed to traditional gender roles (women caretakers at home and men breadwinners outside of the home) which are considered less compatible with divorce.

Perceptions of risk

Christians Freire Boechat (Columbia University) presented a nuanced exploration of masculine identity and risk at the ISA Forum in Cape Town today. His paper, Building a Stronger Man on the Rock of Confusion: Risk, Self-Esteem and Corporate Culture in Brazil, proposed that the Brazilian elite is “immersed in a regime of confusion here widely recognized as ‘corporate culture’ and depend on a masculine legend to solve the
